1.verse: Greetings from Paul - This letter is from Paul, a prisoner for preaching the Good News about Christ Jesus, and from our brother Timothy. I am writing to Philemon, our beloved co-worker,

2.verse: and to our sister Apphia, and to our fellow soldier Archippus, and to the church that meets in your house.

3.verse: May God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ give you grace and peace.

4.verse: Paul’s Thanksgiving and Prayer - I always thank my God when I pray for you, Philemon,

5.verse: because I keep hearing about your faith in the Lord Jesus and your love for all of God’s people.

6.verse: And I am praying that you will put into action the generosity that comes from your faith as you understand and experience all the good things we have in Christ.

7.verse: Your love has given me much joy and comfort, my brother, for your kindness has often refreshed the hearts of God’s people.

8.verse: Paul’s Appeal for Onesimus - That is why I am boldly asking a favor of you. I could demand it in the name of Christ because it is the right thing for you to do.

9.verse: But because of our love, I prefer simply to ask you. Consider this as a request from me—Paul, an old man and now also a prisoner for the sake of Christ Jesus.

10.verse: I appeal to you to show kindness to my child, Onesimus. I became his father in the faith while here in prison.

11.verse: Onesimus hasn’t been of much use to you in the past, but now he is very useful to both of us.

12.verse: I am sending him back to you, and with him comes my own heart.

13.verse: I wanted to keep him here with me while I am in these chains for preaching the Good News, and he would have helped me on your behalf.

14.verse: But I didn’t want to do anything without your consent. I wanted you to help because you were willing, not because you were forced.

15.verse: It seems you lost Onesimus for a little while so that you could have him back forever.

16.verse: He is no longer like a slave to you. He is more than a slave, for he is a beloved brother, especially to me. Now he will mean much more to you, both as a man and as a brother in the Lord.

17.verse: So if you consider me your partner, welcome him as you would welcome me.

18.verse: If he has wronged you in any way or owes you anything, charge it to me.

19.verse: I, PAUL, WRITE THIS WITH MY OWN HAND: I WILL REPAY IT. AND I WON’T MENTION THAT YOU OWE ME YOUR VERY SOUL!

20.verse: Yes, my brother, please do me this favor for the Lord’s sake. Give me this encouragement in Christ.

21.verse: I am confident as I write this letter that you will do what I ask and even more!

22.verse: One more thing—please prepare a guest room for me, for I am hoping that God will answer your prayers and let me return to you soon.

23.verse: Paul’s Final Greetings - Epaphras, my fellow prisoner in Christ Jesus, sends you his greetings.

24.verse: So do Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, and Luke, my co-workers.

25.verse: May the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit.
